qas.question: `Why does thermosphere past the Karman line vary so greatly?
What is commonly known as the boundary of outer space?
What do Astrophysicists use to describe outer space beyond the karman line?
What is more significant than isotropic gas pressure past the Karman line?

answers.text: radiation pressure from the Sun and the dynamic pressure of the solar winds

qas.question: What is commonly known as the boundary of the Sun?
What do astrophysicists use to describe sun radiation?

plausible_answers.text: units of particles per cubic centimetre

qas.question: In what units do astrophysicists use to describe sun radiation?
What does the Sun's atmospheric pressure drop to at 100 km of altitude?
What becomes insidgnificant when it reaches the surface of the moon?

context: Stars, planets, and moons keep their atmospheres by gravitational attraction, and as such, atmospheres have no clearly delineated boundary: the density of atmospheric gas simply decreases with distance from the object. The Earth's atmospheric pressure drops to <b7_0>about 6998320000000000000♠3.2×10−2 Pa<b7_0/> at 100 kilometres (62 mi) of altitude, <a1_0><b4_0>the Kármán line<b4_0/><a1_0/>, which is a common definition of the boundary with outer space. Beyond this line, <b8_0>isotropic gas pressure<b8_0/> rapidly becomes insignificant when compared to <a3_0>radiation pressure from the Sun and the dynamic pressure of the solar winds<a3_0/>, so the definition of pressure becomes difficult to interpret. The thermosphere in this range has large gradients of pressure, temperature and composition, and varies greatly <a0_0>due to space weather<a0_0/>. Astrophysicists prefer to use <a2_0><b5_0>number density<b5_0/><a2_0/> to describe these environments, in <b6_0>units of particles per cubic centimetre<b6_0/>.
